plants.name: Magnolia Ã— soulangeana
plants.description: A deciduous flowering tree known for its large, fragrant, tulip-shaped flowers appearing before the leaves. It thrives in temperate regions and is often one of the first magnolias to bloom in spring.
plants.location: Temperate regions worldwide, originally East Asia
plants.funFact: The Saucer Magnolia was one of the earliest magnolias hybridized for gardens and is famed for its spectacular early spring blooms.

plants.name: Nerium oleander
plants.description: An evergreen shrub adapted to Mediterranean climates, producing clusters of showy, fragrant flowers throughout the growing season. Oleander is drought-tolerant and often blooms profusely in warmer springs.
plants.location: Mediterranean Basin, widely cultivated in subtropical and tropical regions
plants.funFact: Despite its beauty, all parts of oleander are highly toxic due to cardiac glycosides.

plants.name: Erythronium japonicum
plants.description: A perennial wildflower native to East Asia with nodding, lily-like flowers that bloom in early spring under deciduous forests.
plants.funFact: The Asian fawn lily often grows in colonies and is known for its mottled leaves resembling a fawnâ€™s coat.

plants.name: Ceanothus thyrsiflorus
plants.description: An evergreen shrub native to the western United States, particularly California. It produces dense clusters of small blue flowers that bloom in spring, attracting pollinators.
plants.funFact: Ceanothus species fix nitrogen in the soil, enriching poor soils where they grow naturally.
